resources.string: Run exploit to change device keys
Wait for device to stop responding
The device exited AP mode and connected to the custom AP. Reboot the device into AP mode once again (usually only 1 reboot is needed now).
Put the smart device in AP pairing mode. The light (or LED) should be blinking slowly (every 1–2 seconds).

The device doesn't respond to ping requests.

This usually means that an exploit is incompatible, making the device freeze instead of continuing running.

It can also mean that writing the payload didn't succeed, in which case you can try again.
Ping requests are still successful.\n\nThis means that an exploit is incompatible, so the device didn\'t hang/reboot when it was expected to.
Timed out waiting for the step to finish
Couldn\'t connect to the device.\n\nMake sure it\'s in AP mode and that the network is discoverable.
Timed out while scanning for SSID \"%s\".\n\nThe device may have not entered or exited the AP mode.
Good news! The device seems to be exploitable.
Cloudcutting is now in progress.\n\nThis window will show any notices or errors that may be important.
Do not reboot the device. It should be still blinking slowly (since the last Cloudcutter run).\n\nIf it\'s not in pairing mode, you have to go back and choose one of the first two connection modes.
Make sure that the custom AP device is running and idle. The \"%s\" network has to be available for this to succeed.

What is the current state of the device?

This may save you some time if you want to re-run the remote dump feature (i.e. in case of errors).

If in doubt, choose the first option. Other options will not work on a fresh device.

Click OK to choose the state.
